images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Standing Tall." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Standing Tall

data.bodyText: Oaks, magnolias, and hickory trees have withstood strong winds and salt spray to produce a dense forest canopy in this old dune area between Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay. Other trees that have taken root in the sandy soil include redbays, laurel oaks, eastern red cedars, and slash pines. Growing beneath them are yaupon holly, saw palmetto, and-in the wet peaty swales-sawgrass. The gray garlands hanging from live oaks are Spanish moss. Not a true moss but a member of the pineapple family, it absorbs water and food from the air. This mixed woodland serves both as a wildlife habitat and as a storm buffer for the mainland.
data.audioDescription:
425 words
The boardwalk with its wooden curbs curves slightly through the woods on either side. Alongside the walk on the outside of the curve there is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of tree bark and leaves. The vegetation is thick with trees, tall shrubs and saw palmetto, looking almost like a green tunnel in places.

This panel has two parts. The top half is a graphic panel with text and photographs of birds. The bottom half has touchable models of the birds along with labels in raised lettering and in braille.

Text at the top left of the panel reads,

"Oaks, magnolias, and hickory trees have withstood strong winds and salt spray to produce a dense forest canopy in this old dune area between Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay. Other trees that have taken root in the sandy soil include redbays, laurel oaks, eastern red cedars, and slash pines. Growing beneath them are yaupon holly, saw palmetto, and-in the wet peaty swales-sawgrass. The gray garlands hanging from live oaks are Spanish moss. Not a true moss but a member of the pineapple family, it absorbs water and food from the air. This mixed woodland serves both as a wildlife habitat and as a storm buffer for the mainland."

At the right side of the panel is a photograph of a sandy path winding through woods with the twisty branches of live oak trees draped with gray-green masses of Spanish moss and saw palmetto underneath. In the middle of the panel is a smaller photograph of Spanish moss, a long dangling mass of tangled fibers.

Across the lower right of the graphic half of the panel are photographs of the foliage of three trees. At left is pignut hickory which has a compound leaf with five to seven long pointed leaflets.

Next is the eastern red cedar, an evergreen with scale-like foliage on small branchlets.

At right is the southern live oak. It has glossy leaves in the shape of narrow ovals.

Across the bottom of the panel are touchable models of the foliage and bark of these three trees. The label reads,

"Compare the leaves, needles, and bark of trees found in this woodland."

Beginning at the right is the pignut hickory with its compound leaf and rough bark.

Next is the eastern red cedar with its flat scale-like foliage and bark with larger divisions.

At the right end is the live oak with its oval leaves and bark with a roughness intermediate to the other two trees.

End of Description.

data.title: Step Back in History
data.listingDescription: This introductory wayside is located at the Fort Pickens parking lot and introduces visitors to the fort and the self-guiding tour, which is available in this app by navigating to the home screen, selecting tours, and then selecting Fort Pickens Tour. The tour begins immediately inside the sally port.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Step Back in History." Fort in the background.
images.caption: Interpretive Panel: Step Back in History

data.bodyText: Step back in history for a glance of Fort Pickens. To learn more about the fascinating history of this defensive fortification, follow the sidewalk straight ahead and begin your self-guiding tour.
data.audioDescription:
532 words
This point sits at the corner of the parking lot next to the fort. From here a wide sidewalk curves gently to the right towards a rounded arch entrance in the side of the weathered brick fort. Near the entrance another sidewalk curves around to the left towards a small brick building against the wall of the fort.

Left of the entrance weathered brick of the fort's walls rise tall. Small openings covered by iron bars are spaced along the walls. To the right of the entrance a section of the fort's walls is missing giving a glimpse of the arched gallery along the inside of the far wall. A wooden rail fence runs across the opening left by the missing wall section.

Behind you as you face the entrance to the fort, on the far side of this end of the parking lot, is a sidewalk leading towards a group of white wood-frame buildings, some single-story and others two-story.

Interpretive panel: Step back in history.

On the right side of this panel is a map showing the layout of the fort as it looks today. The basic shape of the main fort is five sided with an extended area called a bastion at each corner. The fort is longer in the north-south direction than east-west. Your current location at the corner of the parking lot is at the end of a sidewalk which leads to the entrance in the northern face. The northwest section of the fort, the original Bastion D, is missing.

The open area in the middle of the fort is called the parade. A roughly rectangular structure, called Battery Pensacola, lies across the middle of that space.

Along the eastern side, the left on the diagram, is an outer wall called the counterscarp wall with a dry ditch between it and the main walls of the fort.

A dotted line shows the route of a wheelchair-accessible tour route through the fort. Symbols indicate the location of restrooms and drinking fountain down a sidewalk to the left of the main entrance. The bookstore is located on the right along the entrance tunnel through the north face.

In the bottom left corner of the panel is a black and white photograph looking down into the parade area. Two of the inner walls are visibly lined with arched openings. A pyramid of stacked cannon balls sits in one corner. The caption reads,

"Fort Pickens was a Union fort during the Civil War."

At upper left text reads,

"Fort Pickens played a critical role in an 1800s homeland-security program. Pickens was the largest of four forts the US government built to protect Pensacola Bay and the navy yard. The fort succeeded, not against a foreign invasion, but against the Confederacy during the Civil War. To learn more about the fascinating history of this defensive fortification, follow the sidewalk straight ahead and begin your self-guiding tour. The fort closes at sunset."

Below the text is a quote by Lieutenant Henry W. Halleck, "Report on the Means of Defence," 1843, which reads,

"...as the means of preserving peace, and as obstacles to an invader, [the forts'] influence and power are immense."

End of Description.

data.title: Teeming with Life - Brackenridge Trail
data.listingDescription: From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpecke

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Teeming With Life." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Teeming With Life Site

data.bodyText: From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpeckers fill the air with calls and songs.
data.audioDescription:
453 words
At this point the boardwalk with its wooden curb on each side splits at a "Y" fork. You may follow this loop trail in either direction. At the intersection there is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of some animals that may be found here in the woods. The vegetation on both sides of the walk is thick with trees, tall shrubs and saw palmetto, forming a green tunnel for you to walk through.

This slanted panel has a graphic across the top and touchable models along its bottom. Text at upper left reads,

"From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpeckers fill the air with calls and songs."

The right side of the panel has a photograph of a view through mature tree trunks out into a woodland meadow willed with various shrubs. There are four smaller photographs of common animals. At top left is a red-bellied woodpecker. This bird has a black back with narrow white stripes across it and a red band running from its beak, across the top of it head and down its neck. Below that is a picture of a nine-banded armadillo with its rounded armored back. It has a long snout and small round ears on top of its head.

At right, the top picture shows a patent-leather beetle, all three of its body segments a shiny black. Below that is a coral snake. It has wide bands of black and red separated by narrow bands of yellow.

Touchable models of these four animals are along the bottom of the panel with labels in both braille and raised lettering. The caption reads,

"Trace the shapes of a few animals that live in these coastal woodlands."

Beginning at bottom left is the red-bellied woodpecker. It clings to the right side of a tree trunk, head at the top.

Next is the coral snake. Its head is at the left. Trace its coiled body around to its tail.

Next is the armadillo, snout at the left. Moving to the right there are its pointed ears, it clawed feet underneath and its long tail curved around it.

The last model is the beetle. Its head with its long pinchers is to the right and its oval abdomen with grooves down its length at the left.

End of Description.

data.title: PSSD Wayside-What Time is this Place?
data.listingDescription: Interpretive panel illustrating people enjoying the lakeshore in times past.

images.altText: Illustration of several historic images of people enjoying the lakeshore
images.title: Wayside: What Time is this Place?
images.caption: Interpretive panel illustrating people using the lakeshore in the early 1900s.

data.bodyText:
The lakeshore is always changing. Bays become lakes; dunes become forests. Even the way people enjoy the land has evolved. You can no longer drive on the dunes, but you can kayak the Platte River, hike to Pyramid Point, or camp on the ManitouIslands. Since 1916, the National Park Service has aimed to balance preservation with recreation.

But what moment in time should be preserved? Whose story should emerge along the beaches and trails of Sleeping Bear Dunes: the Anishinaabek, mariners, vacationers? On this drive, we have shared some of each. The future is up to you. Whatmemories will you add to the legacy of the Lakeshore?

A Landscape of Memories
1 Dune Climb, 1900
2 First Car in Leelanau County, c.1910
3 Sunset Shores Drive, 2015
4 D. H. Day State Park, 1924
5 Dune Rides, 1928
6 Glen Lake, c.1900
7 Dune Rides, 1937
8 Dune Skiing, c.1950
9 Sleeping Bear Plateau, 1978
10 Empire Beach, 1915
data.audioDescription: This site's wayside panel, entitled "What Time is this Place?," features 9 color photos-1 large photo serving as the panel's background and 8 smaller photos of various sizes arranged in 2 horizontal rows. These numbered photos, which date from 1900 through 2015, depict various vacationers either hiking, riding in dune vehicles, skiing, swimming, or riding a horse. Text below the wayside's title reads: The lakeshore is always changing. Bays become lakes; dunes become forests. Even the way people enjoy the land has evolved. You can no longer drive on the dunes, but you can kayak the Platte River, hike to Pyramid Point, or camp on the Manitou Islands. Since 1916, the National Park Service has aimed to balance preservation with recreation. But what moment in time should be preserved? Whose story should emerge along the beaches and trails of Sleeping Bear Dunes: the Anishinaabek, mariners, vacationers? On this drive, we have shared some of each. The future is up to you. What memories will you add to the legacy of the Lakeshore? A small building holding 2 vault toilets is located alongside the sidewalk bordering the overlook's parking area. The doors to the toilets face the parking area and are marked with signs indicating the door to the women's toilet on the left and the door to the men's toilet on the right. There is also a large shaded picnic area located slightly uphill from this parking area.

data.title: Restoring a Fort
data.listingDescription: Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the US Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000

images.altText: National Park Service sign in front of the white walls of the Spanish Water Battery.
images.caption: Restoring A Fort Site

data.bodyText: Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the U.S. Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000 new bricks, masons repaired the brickwork. Carpenters rebuilt doors, gates, and a drawbridge. The fort was opened to the public in 1980.
data.audioDescription:
363 words
This tour stop is located on the level space where the cannon were placed on top of the walls enclosing the water battery. All along the outside of this space is a five-foot high outer wall. Spaced against that wall are half-circles made of stone blocks, each circle marking the position of a cannon.

Turning your back to the outer wall, you face the main part of the battery, a gleaming white structure on the other side of the small parade or open space in the middle. The wall you are standing on rises about 10 feet above the parade ground and there is no railing on that side. The parade may be reached by a stair case located in the center of the outer wall.

Behind the white water battery are the red brick walls of Fort Barrancas topped with a protective earth berm.

Interpretive panel: Restoring a Fort.

Text on the upper part of this panel reads,

"Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the US Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000 new bricks, masons repaired the brickwork. Carpenters rebuilt doors, gates, and drawbridge. At one point a Navy explosives crew removed a live cannon ball fired in the Civil War era. The fort was opened to the public in 1980."

At bottom left are two small photographs. The one on the left shows the front of the Spanish Water Battery in 1935. The walls of the fort are dirty with most of the paint gone and stained patches. To the right is the front undergoing restoration by the National Park Service in the 1970s. Scaffolding stretches across the front. Several men with buckets bend to work on the wall.

The background of the panel has a photograph of the fort after restoration, its walls now gleaming white.

End of Description.

data.title: Rugged Casemates
data.listingDescription: You are standing in one of the fort's 21 gun chambers known as casemates. Thirteen casemates on this level housed 10-inch Rodman cannon in the 1860s, but they were never fired in combat. Notice the arched ceiling, which was designed to transfer the massive weight of the brick and cannon above to the vertical piers and to withstand the shock waves from cannon when fired. Between firings the gun crew could close the embrasure-the opening in the wall-with iron shutters to protec

images.altText: Metal sign in front of brick fort walls.
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts: Rugged Casemates

data.bodyText: You are standing in one of the fort's 21 gun chambers known as casemates. Thirteen casemates on this level housed 10-inch Rodman cannon in the 1860s, but they were never fired in combat. Notice the arched ceiling, which was designed to transfer the massive weight of the brick and cannon above to the vertical piers and to withstand the shock waves from cannon when fired. Between firings the gun crew could close the embrasure-the opening in the wall-with iron shutters to protect themselves from enemy fire.
data.audioDescription:
90 words.

This stop is located in front of one of the arched openings that line the inner walls of the fort. All the surfaces are red brick. From the opening a 30-foot long room with an arched ceiling extends to the outer wall of the fort, ending in a small rectangular opening in the thick outer wall. There is a short step up to the floor of the room. Along each side wall are two other arches that lead into similar rooms on either side.

End of Description.

data.title: Rustling Creatures
data.listingDescription: Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice. On spring and summer nights a chorus of barking tree frogs ech

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Rustling Creatures." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Rustling Creatures Site

data.bodyText: Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor or at night, for a chorus of barking tree frogs. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice.
data.audioDescription:
474 words
The boardwalk here continues through the woods on either side. On the south side, there are fewer trees, just tall shrubs and saw palmetto so the sunlight peers through the foliage overhead. On this side of the walk there is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of small animals.

With the panel on your right, there is a bench 30 feet down the walk on the left.

This panel has two parts. The top half is a graphic panel with text and photographs. The bottom half has touchable models of small animals along with labels in raised lettering and in braille.

Text at the top left of the panel reads,

"Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice. On spring and summer nights a chorus of barking tree frogs echoes through the forest."

On the right side of the panel are photographs of six reptiles and amphibians. At upper right is a picture of an Eastern box turtle nestled in dry leaves. Its domed shell is marked in a dappled brown pattern. To the left of that is a slimy salamander on a wide green leaf. Its lizard-shaped body is shiny black and covered with small tan dots.

Below those pictures are four more. Beginning at the left there is a barking tree frog clinging to tree bark. The tiny frog is bright green.

To the right is a pigmy rattlesnake on a palmetto frond. Its long body is covered with circular and rectangular patterns in brown and tan.

Next is a five-lined skink on a birch log. Its lizard-like body has lengthwise stripes in shades of brown with small dots on top. Its head is a rust color.

The last picture is a six-lined roadrunner. This lizard is brown with thin yellow stripes running down its length.

A label at lower left reads,

"Feel the different shapes of these woodland reptiles and amphibians."

Across the bottom of the panel are touchable models of these creatures, all with their heads to the left and tails to the right. Beginning at the left end is the five-lined skink with its very long tail.

Next is the six-lined roadrunner, very similar in shape.

Next is the tiny tree frog with the slimy salamander below it. The salamander has a shorter tail than the other two lizards.

Next is the pygmy rattlesnake, its long body in tight curves.

The final model is the eastern box turtle. Feel the patterns on its back.

End of Description.

data.title: Safer than Brick
data.listingDescription: Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries. Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943.From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatenin

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Safer than Brick." Battery Trueman in the background.
images.caption: Safer than Brick Site

data.bodyText:
Walk to the top of this earthen mound to see Battery Trueman's concrete walls and a scenic view of the harbor entrance. Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries.

Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatening, but they could fire up to 10 rounds a minute. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943.
data.audioDescription:
253 words.

At the top of the panel is a photograph showing the barrels of two artillery guns extending just above the top of the sandy mound that encloses them on the front and sides. Labels identify each as a 3-inch rifle. The caption reads,

"From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatening, but they could fire up to 10 rounds a minute."

Across the bottom of the panel is a photograph looking down onto one of the concrete gun platforms from the top of the surrounding wall as it is seen today. Beyond the battery are low grass-covered dunes with the inlet into Pensacola Bay beyond that. The caption reads,

"Walk to the top of this earthen mound to see Battery Trueman's concrete walls and a scenic view of the harbor entrance."

Text on the left side of the panel reads,

"Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries. Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943."

To the left of the text is a small map showing this western end of the island with Fort Pickens. Your current location at Battery Trueman on the bayside of the island near the western tip is marked.

End of Description.

data.title: Santa Rosa Area Entrance Sign
data.listingDescription: Welcome to the Santa Rosa Area ! The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sand beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Continue your hike on Florida National Scenic Trail along the beach. Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. Restrooms, beach showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at the Opal Beach Complex.

images.altText: Brown, metal National Park Service Sign with the text, "Santa Rosa Area, Gulf Islands National Seashore." The green and brown National Park Service arrowhead sign is on the right.

Visitors can continue to hike on the Florida National Scenic Trail along the beach or enjoy the scenery from a boardwalk trail. Restrooms, showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at the Opal Beach Complex.

Santa Rosa is 43 miles long, and here at the western end we find the widest section. It is here that we also find a well-developed maritime forest of slash pine, live oak and other species commonly found on the mainland. You will be walking directly across to the Gulf of Mexico. During the walk you should notice several changes in y

images.altText: Green and brown plants in the foreground. Pine trees against a blue sky far off in the distance.
images.caption: Dune Nature Trail View From Sign 2

data.bodyText: Santa Rosa Island is 43 miles long, and here about two and a half miles from the west end of the island, you find the widest section. You will also see a well-developed maritime forest of slash pine, live oak and other species commonly found on the mainland.
data.audioDescription: Santa Rosa Island is 43 miles long, and here about two and a half miles from the west end of the island, you find the widest section. You will also see a well-developed maritime forest of slash pine, live oak and other species commonly found on the mainland.

data.title: Shoot and Duck
data.listingDescription: Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages. When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Shoot and Duck." Battery Copper in the background.
images.caption: Shoot and Duck Site

data.bodyText: Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages. When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see here today came from the Smithsonian Institution.
data.audioDescription:
247 words.

At the top of this panel is the long barrel of an artillery gun pointed over a high concrete wall, a man in uniform standing on a platform at its rear. At the right is an inset with a drawing showing the gun having been folded back and lying below the top of the wall. The caption reads,

"The gun carriage arms swung back and lowered the gun."

Across the bottom is a photograph showing a blackened concrete structure with a metal platform on top. The space below the platform is filled with machinery. The caption reads,

"The 6-inch gun has been removed, but the gun carriage remains in this photo taken at Battery Cooper."

Text on the left side of the panel reads,

"Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages. When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see here today came from the Smithsonian Institution."

To the right is a small map showing the end of the island with Fort Pickens. Battery Cooper's position lying to the east of the fort and towards the gulf shoreline is marked.

End of Description.

data.title: SMI Bay Campground
data.listingDescription: The Bay campground sites are tent-only. Once you're settled in, soak in the sights of Lake Michigan from the bluffs on the south side of the island.

images.altText: Four men silhouetted against orange sunset
images.title: SMI Bay Campground
images.caption: South Manitou Island evening.

data.bodyText:
The Bay campground sites are tent-only. Once you're settled in, soak in the sights of Lake Michigan from the bluffs on the south side of the island. Sites are well secluded, and there are several fire rings in the campground that can be shared by campers. The Bay Campground is closest to the dock and has easy access to one of the islands nicest and largest beach.

Once on the island, you won't have an opportunity to purchase food or supplies; the last modern restrooms are near the old boat house and ranger station. There's also a place to fill up your water bottles just outside the bathrooms. Bring water filtration equipment because there are limited sources of purified drinking water. You must carry all of your gear-so travel light, and store your food in hard containers or hung from a line to thwart chipmunks.

Other tips for spending time on South Manitou Island is to remember bug spray, a hat, and any other light medical supplies (band aids for blisters) that might make your trip a bit more comfortable. Know what poison ivy looks like and bring Benadryl/hydrocortisone cream if you know you will immediately react.
data.audioDescription: The Bay Campground is one of three campgrounds located on South Manitou Island and the closest campsite to the island's dock. To reach this campground, which is located close to the beach on the island's crescent-shaped eastern shore, take a half-mile hike north from the dock and Ranger Station. From this campground, there is a largely unobstructed view of the bay to the east. The campsites are situated in dirt-floored clearings surrounded by both deciduous and evergreen trees. Marking the locations of the campground's 25 individual sites and 3 group sites are 28 wooden posts measuring about 3 feet tall with white triangles painted near their tops. Each individual site is limited to 4 people and 2 tents. Each group site is designed to hold from 9 to 20 campers, with a maximum of 10 tents. Group sites are available by reservation only. As you walk around the campsites, you will encounter a number of wooden benches, each constructed of a single wooden timber perched atop 2 smaller wooden blocks positioned at each end. These benches either stand alone or in pairs, and up to 4 such benches surround the campground's metal community fire rings. Each fire ring, which measures approximately 3 feet in diameter and 4 inches high, is topped with a metal grill. These grills can be lifted to place wood in the otherwise open ring. Campers may collect dead and downed wood found on the island to make open fires in these rings during their visit. Visitors are encouraged to bring their own water filtration equipment because there is no source of purified drinking water at the campsites. Campers are also warned to look out for poison ivy, as it is common in this area. Campers must purchase a Backcountry Use Permit before camping at any of the island's campsites.

data.title: Tree House
data.listingDescription: In a wooded area adjacent to the cottage, Dr. John Edwin and Louise Rhoades built a small play house for their daughter, Margaret.

images.altText: Backed by woods, a 2-story weathered gray clapboard structure with a side-facing gable roof
images.title: Treehouse
images.caption: The Treehouse began as a play house for the daughter of the Rhoades family.

data.bodyText:
In 1895 or 1896, a solid-looking shingle-style cottage was constructed here by a couple known as Mr. and Mrs. Hewitt. Shirley Foote Alford described the Hewitts' Cottage Row house, furnished in burlap and calico, as "the prettiest cottage of all.

A few years later the Hewitts, who were immigrants from England, sold the cottage to Dr. John Edwin and Louise Rhoades. In a wooded area adjacent to the cottage, the Rhoades built a small play house for their daughter, Margaret. Later, after Margaret married Roderick Peattie, a lower floor was added to the play house, transforming it into a small, two-story, private cottage for Margaret and Roderick called "the treehouse."

In 1927, soon after inheriting her parent's cottage, Margaret Peattie sold the property to the Manitou Island Association. Jean Lundquist recalled that sometime during 1937-1950s the tree house was occupied by an American Indian man named Raphael. The cottage eventually fell into disuse and was torn down by the Manitou Island Association. However, Margaret and Roderick Peattie's "treehouse" remains standing on the site.

Wouldn't we all love a cottage on Cottage Row

The Cottage Row district is a linear cluster of small, wood-frame houses and other landscape elements sitting along the crest of the beach ridge that overlooks the Life-saving Service complex. It was the island's only speculative resort enterprise, the first of several efforts to turn the island into an exclusive retreat. The individually owned cottages were supported by a communal kitchen and dining facility. This resort setup was common during the nineteenth century and represents a broad trend in recreation on the Great Lakes region.

The buildings face eastward to take advantage of off-shore breezes, as well as superb views of the Manitou Passage and the Michigan mainland. From this prime vantage point, the summer residents could monitor activities of the life-saving service station, as well as steamship traffic through the passage. The configuration of the Cottage Row parcels and accompanying deed restrictions ensured that each property owner would have an unobstructed view of the beach and the Manitou Passage. A board walk, shaded by sugar maple and Norway maple trees, once extended along this area.

The Cottage Row colony provided seasonal employment for year-round island residents. Wives and children of North Manitou farmers and U. S. Life-Saving Service crewmen residents took jobs cooking, cleaning, and doing other domestic chores for Cottage Row residents, in the communal dining room, and at hotel operated by Katie Shepard. For the island's year-round residents, the colony represented a significant source of supplemental cash income. Although some of the cottage owners maintained small gardens, the hotel and summer visitors also provided a much-needed local market for fresh vegetables, fruits, meats, and dairy products.

Because residents and guests took meals at the communal dining room located at the northern end of Cottage Row, individual cottages originally lacked kitchens. After the Cottage Row dining room closed around 1900, Katie Shepard opened her home as a hotel and offered meals to summer residents in a detached dining pavilion. Rear kitchen ells later were added to several Cottage Row houses. Most of the additions probably were constructed during the early 1930s, shortly after Katie Shepard closed her hotel and dining room.

Getting to and from the island and their cottages wasn't always easy as Mrs. Shirley Foote Alford (whose family built one of the first cottages in 1894) explained:
"When people were planning to leave the island, their trunks were loaded on the farm wagon which would go to the top of the hill running down to the dock. There the wagon would wait until the steamer came in close and blew her whistle. If it was three whistles, wagon and people hurried down to the dock to see the boat land. If four whistles were sounded (urgent-danger and distress signal). We all went down as fast as possible to the Life Saving Station where passengers, trunks, baby carriages, ice boxes, etc. were taken out to the steamer in the Life-Saving Service surfboat, rowed by the crew, each man with an oar and the captain steering with a long oar in the stern."
data.audioDescription: Backed by woods and standing beside a tree stump measuring about 4 feet tall is a 2-story weathered gray clapboard structure with a side-facing gable roof and a foundation faced with wooden shingles. This building was once a private cottage known as the Treehouse. The Treehouse began as a play house for the daughter of the Rhoades family, who lived in the main cottage on this lot in the early 1900s. The main cottage, which was built by the Hewitt family around 1895, is no longer standing. Located to the right of the structure's right-most upper-story window, and situated at least 12 feet above the grassy ground, is a rectangular door opening covered with a wooden board. Two of the 3 small windows here also appear to be at least partially boarded up. There are no doors at ground level on this side of the building. Directly behind the tree trunk, which is situated near the building facade's left side, is a small one-story addition with a shed roof that extends from the building's left end. There is a 6-pane window located on the side of the addition that faces the tree trunk.

data.title: Wildlife Signatures
data.listingDescription: Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Wildlife Signatures." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Wildlife Signatures Site

data.bodyText: Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence.
data.audioDescription:
510 words
The boardwalk with its wood curbs makes a broad "s" curve here through the dense woods on either side. Sunlight peeps its way through the foliage overhead, but both sides are thick with small tree trunks, shrubs and saw palmetto. At the side of the walk is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of animal footprints.

This panel has two parts. The top half is a graphic panel with text and photographs. The bottom half has touchable models of animal footprints along with labels in raised lettering and in braille.

Text at the top left of the panel reads,

"Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence."

To the right are photographs of five animals common in this woodland. Across the top, beginning at the left is an eastern mole. The small mammal peers out from a hole in the dirt covered with thick gray fur except for its smooth pointed snout and its longs claws on its front feet.

Next is a racoon, perched on the edge of a hole in a tree trunk. He looks at us with his black mask, white nose and brown and black ringed tail.

At the right is an eastern gray squirrel sitting on a tree branch. Its body is gray with a white underbelly and its long busy tail makes an "S" curve over its back.

Below these are two more pictures. At left is a gray fox trotting across a stony patch in tall grass. Its pointed nose is black and it has a red patch behind its ears. Its long bushy tail has a black band down its top.

The final picture shows a Virginia opossum. It clings to a narrow branch. It has a white face and pointed snout with a pink tip. Its body has thick gray fur but its tail is furless and whip-like.

A label invites you to touch the footprint impressions below of a few mammal species that live in the coastal plain.

Beginning at bottom left are mole footprints. The front foot on top is wider, almost round, while the rear foot below is long and narrow.

Next are gray fox prints. These are similar to dog footprints, with a central pad and four large toes on each foot.

Next is a racoon, similar to a tiny human's hand and foot, only slightly longer and with longer toes.

Next is the gray squirrel. Its prints are like the racoon's but smaller and narrower.

The final set of prints are from an opossum. Its front print is roughly rectangular with the five pointed toes prints spread wide. The hind foot is long and has one to separate from the rest, like a mitten.

End of Description.

data.title: Dock House and Information
data.listingDescription: The dockhouse on Garden Key

images.title: Garden Key Dock House
images.caption: The dock house on Garden Key viewed from the harbor.

data.bodyText:
The dock house at Garden Key is located on the dock where the ferry lands. It is dead center of Fort Jefferson's only entrance, the sally port.  

Changing Rooms
There are changing rooms available in the dock house on the East side. The rooms are open 24/7 and are handicap accessible with handrails and benches. 

Information Room
On the West side of the dock house, there is an information room with park brochures. Private boaters can pick up and fill out a boat permit at this location. Useful boating, diving and fishing material can be found here, along with a marine band radio for required visitor use. As soon as available, tide charts and weather are posted in this room. 
The dock house information room is a great place to start your Dry Tortugas visit. You can learn more about what to do and find information to help you have a safe and enjoyable time.

Fee Station
You can pay your park entrance and camping fees here.

data.title: Jeff Busby Picnic Area, Milepost 193.1
data.listingDescription: Jeff Busby Picnic Area is a great place to grill grub, eat and take a stroll through the woods. You can walk or choose to drive all the way up to the top on one of Mississippi's highest point, 584 feet above sea level, and about 200 feet higher than the picnic area.

images.altText: A family heading down step on a trail with a sign that says Little Mountain Trail
images.title: Trail next to the picnic area
images.caption: Little Mountain Trail next to the Jeff Busby Picnic Area.

data.bodyText: This shady area is a great place to have a picnic. Grill some grub, and have a picnic, then take a walk on the Little Mountain Trail. It's elevation is only 584 feet at the top, about 200 feet higher than the picnic area. Or you can drive there easily. The picnic area has 39 tables, three are accessible.

data.title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: Honoring our Salmon at Ainsworth Greenspace
data.listingDescription: Three twelve-foot-tall sculptures topped with bronze totem heads, each one representing a being from native american legend. The sculptures face inward toward each other, forming a small plaza between them. A river-like pathway with a bronze spiral inset is in the center.

images.credit: "River Spirits" by brx0 is licensed under CC BY-SA 2.0
images.altText: Three statues from native legend look towards each other
images.title: Lillian Pitt Honoring Our Salmon
images.caption: The sculptures are inspired by local trees.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
data.bodyText:
Twelve-foot-tall sculptures inspired by trees of nearby forests complete a series of totem poles in Ainsworth Greenspace. Bronze totem heads representing legendary or sacred beings sit atop the three totems: “She Who Watches” by Lillian Pitt, “Salmon” by Ken MacKintosh, and “Crow” by Rick Bartow. The sculptures face inward, forming a small plaza with a river-like pathway with a bronze spiral inset in the center.

Describing the artwork, Lillian Pitt states, “We wanted to do something that was in keeping with the diverse neighborhoods that were nearby, and we wanted to do something to honor the maple trees that used to grow on that spot. We ended up using legendary images from different tribal traditions to represent the diversity in Native American culture, and we placed these giant images on top of pillars in the shape of maple tree trunks.”

The educational aspect of the Ainsworth project was enhanced by including a poetry project for students at the Ockley Green Middle School . Students learned to write poetry, and in keeping with the aims of the greenspace goals, were inspired to write about nature. The class was taught by collaborating artist and author, Gail Tremblay, who has worked frequently with Lillian over the years. Many of the resulting children’s poems are engraved onto the maple-tree columns that serve as the stands for the totems.

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
data.audioDescription: Three twelve-foot-tall sculptures topped with bronze totem heads, each one representing a being from native american legend. The sculptures face inward toward each other, forming a small plaza between them. A river-like pathway with a bronze spiral inset is in the center.

data.title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: River Guardian on the Willamette River
data.listingDescription: With a headdress of steel adorning her lead crystal glass head, and a body constructed of both copper and steel, River Guardian stands nine-feet tall along the banks of the Willamette River at the South Waterfront in Portland, Oregon. She watches with two faces: one looking toward the river, and one looking in the opposite direction, signifying her protection of people on both water and land.
tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
data.bodyText:
With a headdress of steel adorning her lead crystal glass head, and a body constructed of both copper and steel, River Guardian stands nine-feet tall along the banks of the Willamette River at the South Waterfront in Portland, Oregon. She watches with two faces: one looking toward the river, and one looking in the opposite direction, signifying her protection of people on both water and land. This public art installation is the result of a collaboration between Lillian Pitt and Mikkel Hilde. The artwork was commissioned through a joint effort between the Portland State University Native American community and Portland City Parks.

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

“I have a very strong commitment to helping in any way that I can when it comes to shining a light on the cultures of river people. That’s because my ancestors all lived along the Columbia River, and depended largely on fishing for their livelihood. So I was thrilled to be able to bring River Guardian to the South Waterfront.”

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
data.audioDescription: A nine-foot-tall statue on the banks of the Willamette River made of steel, copper, and glass. The body is made of copper and steel, while the head is circular and made of lead crystal glass. The head is set in an abstract steel headdress.

data.title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: Rosa Parks Station
data.listingDescription: The art project at the Rosa Parks station was completed by a team including Native American artist Lillian Pitt, Ken MacKintosh, Rick Bartow, Elizabeth Woody, and Gail Tremblay. The artists used traditional motifs to symbolize the life-sustaining relationships of nature. Pitt served as team leader of five members to complete her vision.

images.credit: "Rosa Parks Station" by TriMet is licensed under CC BY 2.0
images.altText: Native American symbols adorn columns, railway panels and benches
images.title: Rosa Parks Station
images.caption: Rosa Parks Station

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
data.bodyText:
Portland’s public transit system offers travelers a unique, rich emersion into the local art scene. The Tri-County Metropolitan Transportation District of Oregon (Tri-Met) promotes transit use and community pride by integrating permanent and temporary art works that celebrate the contributions of the cultural richness in the region.

The art project at the Rosa Parks station was completed by a team including Native American artist Lillian Pitt, Ken MacKintosh, Rick Bartow, Elizabeth Woody, and Gail Tremblay. The artists used traditional motifs to symbolize the life-sustaining relationships of nature. Pitt served as team leader of five members to complete her vision. She states, “The Interstate project was the first public art project I worked on. At the time, there was not one public art project in Portland that was done by a Native American artist. So I thought, that’s not right, and I went ahead and applied for the job.”

Artistic interpretations of historic petroglyphs from the Columbia River Gorge appear on columns, custom benches, and railing panels. A traditional basket weave pattern is repeated in the pavement. And, at the ends of each of the shelters near the apex of the roofline, are sculptured images of birds, fishing apparatus and other symbols of cultural significance. “I designed the bricks into a basket design, the fence railings and the gable ends,” states Pitt.

Pitt’s artwork along the Tri-Met has become known for an iconography rooted in the Columbia River petroglyphs of her ancestors. Through her use of this and other petroglyph symbols, Pitt has helped to bring the Indigenous iconography of the Columbia River to the public eye and affirm the ancient as well as contemporary Indigenous presence in the region.

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.

More information about artwork along the Tri-Met can be found here: https://trimet.org/publicart/index.htm
data.audioDescription: Traditional Native American motifs based on artistic interpretations of petroglyphs from the Columbia River symbolizing the life-sustaining relationships of nature adorn columns, benches, and railing panels at this transit station.

data.title: Lillian Pitt Public Artwork: “Voices,” at the Oregon Convention Center
data.listingDescription: Lillian Pitt’s “Voices” is a series of twenty six bronze relief plaques located in the Oregon Convention Center and are part of the Center’s Public Art project. Her work is the largest collection of public art by a Native American artist in any public space within the City of Portland. Ten artists were selected through a public invitation process to produce work for the center’s permanent collection, one of the most varied convention center art programs in the country.

images.credit: "Oregon Convention Center" by sd is licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 2.0
images.altText: A large circular modern building with two glass spires rising from the roof
images.title: Oregon Convention Center
images.caption: The Oregon Convention Center

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
data.bodyText:
Lillian Pitt’s “Voices” is a series of twenty six bronze relief plaques located in the Oregon Convention Center and are part of the Center’s Public Art project. Her work is the largest collection of public art by a Native American artist in any public space within the City of Portland. Ten artists were selected through a public invitation process to produce work for the center’s permanent collection, one of the most varied convention center art programs in the country.

The twenty-six plaques in the exhibit represent the voices of Native people throughout the region. Lillian is a descendent of Wasco, Yakama and Warm Springs ancestors, and she felt it was her obligation to honor all of the Native peoples of the region in her work.

Lillian states, “My goal wasn’t just to produce public art but to educate viewers about the rich cultures and history of the various Native peoples who lived throughout Oregon.” She further states, “We titled the work “Voices” because we thought of the plaques as giving our ancestors a voice … giving them an opportunity to be heard in this modern world where the memory of them is otherwise being drowned by progress.”

Lillian Pitt is a Pacific Northwest Native American artist. She was born and raised on the Warm Springs reservation in Oregon and her ancestors lived in and near the Columbia River Gorge for over 10,000 years. The focus of her work is on creating contemporary fine art pieces that delight today’s art lovers, and at the same time, honor the history and legends of her people.

For more information about Lillian Pitt’s work and a list of her other public art pieces to view in the area, please visit http://lillianpitt.com.
data.audioDescription: Paved city street, circular tan building, blue glass spires rise from the roof. Two flag poles stand on either side of the sidewalk leading to the entrance.

data.title: SMI Life-Saving Station
data.listingDescription: The United States Life-Saving Service (USLSS) station on South Manitou Island was built in 1901 and officially opened in August of 1902 with a Keeper and a crew of six surfmen.

images.altText: White clapboard building with three gabled dormer windows and covered front porch
images.title: SMI Life-Saving Station
images.caption: The Life-Saving Station

data.bodyText:
The United States Life-Saving Service (USLSS) station on South Manitou Island was built in 1901 and officially opened in August of 1902 with a Keeper and a crew of six surfmen. From 1901 to 1915, surfmen gave aid not only to mariners and shipwreck victims, but also to civilians living on the island. The USLSS reports for South Manitou reveal that surfmen often used their boats to take gravely ill islanders to the mainland doctor or to bring the doctor to the island. They also helped put out fires at farm houses and on board ships, provided basic first aid, and rescued people and animals from drowning.

USLSS Keepers and Surfmen became members of the island's close-knit community. The station house only provided housing for the Keeper and his family and the single men of the crew. Many island residents turned to the USLSS for work when jobs in logging and farming began to decline. Often, family members served on the USLSS crews together and over time, some families had a several generations of men that served the USLSS.

Surfmen stories

Gerald Crowner
Gerald E. Crowner served as a surfman for the United States Coast Guard on South Manitou Island from 1926 to 1928. He published a memoir, The South Manitou Story, of his time on the island in 1982. His book is filled with short stories, poems, and photos that bring his service on the island to life for readers today.

The South Patrol on a Windy Fall Night
by Gerald E. Crowner

I walked alone
one starlit
windy night
and saw the clouds,
like stately galleons
pass in flight,
eclipsing the star-beams
with shadowy grace,
as they twinkled
and sparkled
through unending space.
And the surf
came in blasting,
with crests flying high,
like the manes of wild horses
against the dark sky.
And over my soul
came a glorious peace,
as I walked
in the starlight
beside turbulent seas.

John F. Tobin
John F. Tobin lived on South Manitou Island as a boy. His grandfather, John K. Tobin, served in both the Coast Guard and the Lighthouse Service on South Manitou. John's father, Harold, was born on the island and served at the Coast Guard station there until WWII. While Harold served in the war, John F. and his family moved off of the island. In 2010, John F. was interviewed for an oral history project at Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore. He shared stories about growing up on South Manitou, attending school, and playing pranks. He was a self-proclaimed "stinker" and "rascal" during his boyhood days! In this interview clip, John describes the life-saving drills practiced by the Coast Guard, the Navy visiting on the Fourth of July, and the trouble he got into playing with black powder.

U.S. Life-Saving Service

Congress established the United States Life-Saving Service (USLSS) in 1871 in an effort to reduce the number of lives lost on the oceans and the Great Lakes due to shipwrecks. The surfmen of the USLSS became known as "storm warriors" and "storm fighters." Their unofficial motto was, "you have to go out, but you don't have to come back." USLSS crews braved perilous conditions to save shipwreck victims from certain doom.

The narrow Manitou passage, which runs between the islands and the mainland, is one of the most dangerous on the Great Lakes. Ships have to make several turns here, and because of the shoals surrounding the islands, `they fell asleep. At night, surfmen patrolled the beaches. Each station handled beach patrol a little differently. If stations were fairly close to each other, surfmen on beach patrol carried a small medallion, called a check, which was inscribed with the name of his station and his number. During beach patrol, the surfman hiked down the beach the required distance, up to four or five miles, where he met a surfman from the neighboring station and they exchanged checks. Each surfman turned the check into their Keeper in the morning as a way to prove that he had completed his patrol. Other stations, especially isolated stations such as South Manitou, used time clocks in order to prove that surfmen completed their patrols. A surfman would carry the small clock on a strap over his shoulder as he made their way down the beach. At the end of the patrol was a wooden post in the sand containing a key. The surfman inserted the key into the clock, which recorded the time on a roll of paper. Not only did this prove that surfmen completed their patrols, but also that patrols were completed on time.

The crew also responsible for maintaining the station; this included keeping it clean. Every morning they cleaned the lamps and lanterns and trimmed and filled them. They swept the hallways; filled wood boxes; swept sidewalks; cleaned cuspidors and ash trays; dusted the stairway; and made their beds neat and smooth. On Saturdays, or scrub day, all station floors were scrubbed, windows washed, and brass polished.

Surfmen also kept the buildings and equipment gleaming. Maintenance of buildings usually meant repainting the buildings and cutting and splitting wood (enough wood for the two kitchen ranges and two wood burners in the station). But when needed, expanded to renovation tasks like putting on new roofs, laying new flooring, building new outhouses, and even laying new sod (and watering that sod).

The main duty of the Service was the protection of life and property on the water. But local citizens often looked to the crew when they needed help. An annual report from 1895 lists some of these "Miscellaneous Services": surfmen rigging the rope on the flagstaff of the county building, extinguishing 21 fires in homes or buildings, catching a runaway horse, repairing a wagon owned by two ladies who were kept out of the rain at the station while the surfmen worked on their buggy, finding a child lost in the woods, helping sick people get home. And once, helping a farmer get his horse out of a well.

Living at the USLSS

The crew spent most of their down time on the first floor (the sleeping quarters upstairs wasn't heated). The crew's quarters served as a lounging room. According to Gerald Crowner a surfman on South Manitou in 1926, "A round oak table stood by the east window with a big oil lamp suspended over it. Near the table was a wall bookcase full of books that were seldom read. In the southeast corner stood the little stand that harbored our Monkey Ward record player and the pile of records that were so often played. The big wood burner occupied a space near the south wall, near the door that led to the hallway. Rows of hooks also lined the west wall, where one could hang up coats and caps. Six or eight chairs were lined up under the double window on the north wall that faced the bay."

In the fall and winter months, the monotony of long cold months was broken up by sharing stories and tall tales around the wood burner. Neighbors often stopped in to add their tales. Mail days were happy days. They all looked forward to letters from home, friends, and sweethearts and often gathered at the post office at mail time waiting for the letters to be sorted.

Many of the surfmen had their own, small houses nearby. This allowed them to be with their families. The surfmen had one day off every 8 days, otherwise they were on duty 24 hours a day. Regulations required the men to sleep at the station except for their day off. But some keepers were more lenient allowing men to stay in their cottages near the station where they could be called quickly to come in an emergency. This allowed the men to people spend a little more time at home.

There was a telephone cable that snaked its way from Sleeping Bear Point through South Manitou on to the North Manitou Lighthouse and Coast Guard Station and homes. Gerald Crowner a South Manitou surfman in 1926 tells us, "One of the crewmen on North Manitou played the mouth organ, and he played it beautifully. Quite often, he would call me when I had the midnight to two watch and play songs for me. He could play just about everything in the book. . . .Many times I would call Sleeping Bear Point, and he would call the operator at Maple City, and all of us would enjoy his music and carry on a four-way conversation."
data.audioDescription: Located on a small beach area near the U.S. Lifesaving and Coastguard Station are 6 wooden picnic tables with attached benches. Take care as you approach the tables, as the sand underfoot may be uneven and/or dotted with small rocks and spindly plants. Only a few low white rocks situated 4 or so feet beyond the tables separate the picnic area from a short drop to the shore of Manitou Passage. Visible beyond the water is a low landmass-the Michigan mainland, and specifically Sleeping Bear Point, located about 7 miles away.

data.title: SMI Popple Campground
data.listingDescription: South Manitou Island has scenic campsites within quiet campgrounds. The Popple Campground is the furthest from the dock (about 3.5 miles), and is likely to have fewer people camping in its seven individual sites.

images.altText: Three pine trees in grassy dune with view of blue lake and sandy beach in background
images.title: SMI Popple Campground
images.caption: Camping on South Manitou Island

data.bodyText:
South Manitou Island has scenic campsites within quiet campgrounds. The Popple Campground is the furthest from the dock (about 3.5 miles), and is likely to have fewer people camping in its seven individual sites. Once you're settled in, take a trip to the beach on the northern tip of the island!

Campers must purchase a Backcountry Use Permit before camping. Park passes and permits are available at the Fishtown dock in Leland during the summer months. During the off-season, you can contact the Philip A. Hart Visitor Center in Empire for permits.

Once on the island, you won't have an opportunity to purchase food or supplies; the last modern restrooms are near the old boat house and ranger station. There's also a place to fill up your water bottles just outside the bathrooms. Bring water filtration equipment because there are limited sources of purified drinking water. You must carry all of your gear-so travel light, and store your food in hard containers or hung from a line to thwart chipmunks.

Other tips for spending time on South Manitou Island is to remember bug spray, a hat, and any other light medical supplies (bandaids for blisters) that might make your trip a bit more comfortable. Know what poison ivy looks like and bring Benadryl/hydrocortisone cream if you know you will immediately react.
data.audioDescription: The Popple Campground is one of three campgrounds located on South Manitou Island and the furthest campsite from the island's dock. It is an approximately 3.5-mile hike from the dock and Ranger Station to the campground, which is located close to the beach on the island's northern tip. From the Popple Campground, visitors are offered a clear view of North Manitou Island as well as easy access to the beach fronting Lake Michigan. With 7 individual campsites, this is the smallest of the island's campgrounds. Standing to the right of the narrow dirt trail leading to the campground is a wooden post supporting a small wooden sign with the word "Popple" carved into its face. Also carved into the sign is an upward facing arrow and an image of a tent. The campsites are nestled in dirt-floored clearings within a forest of tall leafy trees. The location of each individual campsite is marked by a wooden post measuring about 3 feet tall with a white triangle painted near the top. Each of the 7 campsites is limited to 4 people and 2 tents. Take care as you step around the campground as you may encounter some fallen logs and piles of stones near the various sites. Please note that there are no fire rings at this campground. Visitors are encouraged to bring their own water filtration equipment because there is no source of purified drinking water at the campsites. Campers are also warned to look out for poison ivy, as it is common in this area. Campers must purchase a Backcountry Use Permit before camping at any of the island's campsites.

data.title: SMI Weather Station Campground
data.listingDescription: The Weather Station campground overlooks Lake Michigan on the island's south side about a mile beyond the lighthouse. The campsites are located within a forested area and are fairly well secluded from each other.

images.altText: Hiker on trail through tall trees and verdant vegetation
images.title: SMI Weather Station Campground
images.caption: On the way to the campground.

data.bodyText:
The Weather Station campground overlooks Lake Michigan on the island's south side about a mile beyond the lighthouse. The campsites are located within a forested area and are fairly well secluded from each other. This location offers inspiring views of the Manitou Passage and Sleeping Bear Dunes on the mainland. The lighthouse, Lake Florence, the Morazan and Giant Cedars are all within easy walking distance. Follow the signs to take a pleasant walk along a woodland path, past the lighthouse to this campsite or follow Burdick Road, turning left at Ohio Road for a less scenic, but easier walk.

There are 20 individual sites (maximum of 4 people or 2 tents per site) and 3 group sites (maximum of 20 people or 10 tents per site). There are several fire rings in the campground that can be shared by campers. Bring water filtration equipment because there is no source of purified drinking water.

Once on the island, you won't have an opportunity to purchase food or supplies; the last modern restrooms are near the old boat house and ranger station. There's also a place to fill up your water bottles just outside the bathrooms. Bring water filtration equipment because there are limited sources of purified drinking water. You must carry all of your gear-so travel light, and store your food in hard containers or hung from a line to thwart chipmunks.

Other tips for spending time on South Manitou Island is to remember bug spray, a hat, and any other light medical supplies (band aids for blisters) that might make your trip a bit more comfortable. Know what poison ivy looks like and bring Benadryl/hydrocortisone cream if you know you will immediately react.
data.audioDescription: The Weather Station Campground is one of three campgrounds located on South Manitou Island. To reach this campground, which overlooks Lake Michigan from the bluffs on the island's south side, follow the wooded trail about 1.3 miles past the lighthouse located south and west of the dock. Standing alongside the narrow dirt trail leading into the campground are at least 2 wooden posts supporting small wooden signs with the words "Weather Station Campground" carved into their faces. Another wooden post carved with the words "Lake Access" is painted pale blue on its top section only to highlight the word "lake." The Weather Station Campground is largely forested with its campsites well secluded from each other. There are 20 individual sites and 3 group sites here, with their locations indicated by 23 wooden posts measuring about 3 feet tall and with white triangles painted near their tops. Each individual site is limited to 4 people and 2 tents. Each group site is designed to hold from 9 to 20 campers, with a maximum of 10 tents. Group sites are available by reservation only. As you walk around each campsite, you may encounter one or more wooden benches, each constructed of a single wooden timber perched atop 2 smaller wooden blocks positioned at each end. There are also several low metal community fire rings topped with metal grills. These grills can be lifted to place wood into the otherwise open rings, which measure approximately 3 feet in diameter and 4 inches high. Campers may collect dead and downed wood found on the island to make open fires in these rings during their visit. Visitors are encouraged to bring their own water filtration equipment because there is no source of purified drinking water at the campsites. Campers are also warned to look out for poison ivy, as it is common in this area. Campers must purchase a Backcountry Use Permit before camping at any of the island's campsites.

data.title: Mandan Hidatsa Arikara Tourism Earth Lodge Village
data.listingDescription: The three affiliated tribes of the Upper Missouri River Valley, the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara, perfected the construction of their earth lodge homes over hundreds of years of life on the harsh Northern Plains. Masters of agriculture, the tribes settled near the fertile banks of the river and built large circular homes 30–60 feet across to accommodate multiple families, typically sisters and their kin.

images.credit: "Mandan Earthlodge 01" by SnoShuu is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 2.0
images.altText: A domed earth structure covered in grass with a door going inside and poles around the door
images.title: A Mandan Earth Lodge
images.caption: A reconstructed Mandan earth lodge in North Dakota

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
data.bodyText:
The three affiliated tribes of the Upper Missouri River Valley, the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara, perfected the construction of their earth lodge homes over hundreds of years of life on the harsh Northern Plains. Masters of agriculture, the tribes settled near the fertile banks of the river and built large circular homes 30–60 feet across to accommodate multiple families, typically sisters and their kin.

Construction of the heavily insulated earth and wooden homes was overseen by elder women within the community. Women also managed most of the building, framing the cottonwood posts and rafters, and filling the frame with willow branches, dried gasses and thick sod. Each house would take between seven and ten days to build and had to be reconstructed about every ten years. These homes were used until the late 19th century, when timber homes replaced the traditional style, and earth lodges became a ceremonial structure.

Today, you can experience these sacred structures at the reconstructed Earthlodge Village on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation near New Town, North Dakota. Located on the picturesque shores of Lake Sakakawea, you can stay the night in an earth lodge, take a trail ride, hear stories of the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara peoples from cultural interpreters, and experience living culture at powwows and other events throughout the year.

data.title: North Coaling Docks
data.listingDescription: North Coaling Pier Pilings

images.altText: A free diver moves swiftly through the pier pilings as tiny silver fish make a halo around her.
images.title: North Coaling Pier Pilings
images.caption: A free diver moves gracefully through the pier pilings as tiny fish create a halo around her.

data.bodyText: In the late 1800s the US Navy built coaling warehouses and piers to refuel their ships. Eventually a particularly strong hurricane saw to the destruction of these structures and the Navy decided not to rebuild them. Fortunately for the visitor today, the pilings these piers were built upon did survive and offer an excellent opportunity to see some of the park’s larger marine animals. The shelter created by the pilings, mixed with a deep drop off into the dredged channel, attract large grouper, tarpon, barracudas, and the occasional shark. You can also expect to see a variety of smaller fish and colorful coral living on and around these pilings. Remember to recreate responsibly, there is no lifeguard on duty and the nearest medical help is 70 miles away. The park is a no touch no take area. All coral, reef fish and cultural artifacts are protected. Maintaining at least an arms distance from the bottom or any corals is a best practice for personal and resource safety. There is no fishing allowed in this area.

data.title: PSSD Wayside-The Legend
data.listingDescription: Interpretive panel about the Legend of Sleeping Bear

images.altText: Illustration of mother bear and two cubs walking toward a lakeshore
images.title: Wayside: The Legend
images.caption: Interpretive panel illustrating the legend of sleeping bear.

data.bodyText:
Once, long ago, in the land called Wisconsin across the great lake, there was terrible hunger and many people died. A bear and two little cubs were trying to leave that place and come around the lake where there would be more food.

They walked for many days on the beach together, but after a while the two little cubs began to whimper with hunger and so the bear decided to swim across the rest of the lake. They waded into the water, one cub on each side of the bear, and they swam off into the lake a long way. After a while the cubs began to get very tired, and so the bear said, 'Try hard, the land is not very far.' And very soon they did come in sight of land. But gradually the cubs got weaker, and only ten miles away, one cub sank into the water. Soon after the other also drowned.

The bear's heart was broken, but she could do nothing. She waded ashore and lay down, looking out on the water where her cubs had died. Eventually, both of them came to the surface as two little islands, and so the bear still lies there atop the dunes, looking after her children.

Speak Anishinaabemowin
The Anishinaabek told parables like this one to teach cultural values. They shared these teachings in the winter around their wigwam fires. For a people dependent on harvesting their own food, famine was the great fear. The choice the bear (makwa) had to make between starvation or a perilous journey would've been familiar to all.

Agoding kitchi jajigo iiaing agaming Wisconsin aki nongo
Once long time ago out where across the sea Wisconsin land now
ejnika-demigog, baka dewin gidago, apitchigo gisnagad gibati-nad
it is called, hunger existed very much difficult plentiful
gaie nibowin. Makwa miniwa nij makonsag, tibeiw, nibina so-gwan
and death. Bear also two little bears on the beach many days
gib-mosewag. Manpi agaming bagosend-mowad wibi-jawad.
they walked. Over here across the sea they were wishing to come here they.
Mawipi mises-sesnand-monid makonsan. Miiwi gi-gijen-dang
After a while whimpering with hunger they little cubs. So then made up her mind
makwa ji-manen-dong jidka-mada-gawad.
bear to attempt they to swim across.
