Text below the wayside's title tells us: Once, long ago, in the land called Wisconsin across the great lake, there was terrible hunger and many people died. A bear and two little cubs were trying to leave that place and come around the lake where there would be more food. They walked for many days on the beach together, but after a while the two little cubs began to whimper with hunger and so the bear decided to swim across the rest of the lake. They waded into the water, one cub on each side of the bear, and they swam off into the lake a long way. After a while the cubs began to get very tired, and so the bear said, 'Try hard, the land is not very far.' And very soon they did come in sight of land. But gradually the cubs got weaker, and only ten miles away, one cub sank into the water. Soon after the other also drowned. The bear's heart was broken, but she could do nothing. She waded ashore and lay down, looking out on the water where her cubs had died. Eventually, both of them came to the surface as two little islands, and so the bear still lies there atop the dunes, looking after her children. To the right of this text is another smaller title: "Speak Anishinaabemowin." Text below this title tells us: The Anishinaabek told parables like this one to teach cultural values. They shared these teachings in the winter around their wigwam fires. For a people dependent on harvesting their own food, famine was the great fear. The choice the bear, or makwa, had to make between starvation or a perilous journey would've been familiar to all. Below this text is a short excerpt from this parable-written in both English, which appears in black lettering, and Anishinaabemowin, which appears in red. This parable echoes the legend presented in the first section of audio description for this panel.

data.title: PSSD Wayside-Stories in the Sky
data.listingDescription: Stories in the Sky Interpretive Panel

images.altText: Illustration of the night sky and constellations
images.title: Wayside: Stories of the Sky
images.caption: Interpretive panel illustrating the night sky and stars.

data.bodyText:
Throughout time and across the world, people have gazed in wonder as points of light circled above them, reappearing in the same position at the same time each year. Like many cultures, the first people of this region named constellations after characters and objects from stories that illustrated their worldview. Where some see the Big Dipper, the Anishinaabek, saw an animal called a fisher whose travels around the North Star (Polaris) come to life in the legend excerpted below.

The Legend of Fisher and Skyland
Winter
One year, the winter did not end. A squirrel said to Fisher, "Go to the place where the skyland is closest to the Earth. There the skypeople are keeping summer. Go there and bring warm weather back." Fisher and his friends agreed and set out for skyland.

Spring
Otter and Lynx could not break through the sky, but Wolverine did. Fisher jumped through the hole. Finding the world's birds caged, Fisher released them. He then made the hole bigger and summer began to leak into the land below, melting the snow.

Summer
The sky people chased after Fisher. But Fisher knew that if he didn't make the hole big enough, the sky people would seal it up and winter would rule again. So he kept chewing the sky hole larger, while dodging the arrows of the sky people.

Autumn
Finally, however, an arrow struck Fisher just about his tail. He rolled over on his back and began to fall towards the world below. Gitchee Manitou honored him for his bravery and placed him among the stars. Each year he circles the heavens.
data.audioDescription: You are standing in front of a wayside panel entitled "Stories in the Sky," which features a large blue map of a star-filled night sky. Superimposed over the map are thin blue and white lines connecting the stars of about a dozen constellations, which are also labeled by name. Text under the wayside's title tells us: Throughout time and across the world, people have gazed in wonder as points of light circled above them, reappearing in the same position at the same time each year. Like many cultures, the first people of this region named constellations after characters and objects from stories that illustrated their worldview. Where some see the Big Dipper, the Anishinaabek saw an animal called a fisher whose travels around the North Star (or Polaris) come to life in the legend excerpted below. Below the sky map are small drawings showing the changing positions of the Big Dipper in the winter, spring, summer, and autumn. The accompanying excerpt, entitled "The Legend of Fisher and Skyland," reads: Winter: One year, the winter did not end. A squirrel said to Fisher, "Go to the place where the skyland is closest to the Earth. There the skypeople are keeping summer. Go there and bring warm weather back." Fisher and his friends agreed and set out for skyland. Spring: Otter and Lynx could not break through the sky, but Wolverine did. Fisher jumped through the hole. Finding the world's birds caged, Fisher released them. He then made the hole bigger and summer began to leak into the land below, melting the snow. Summer: The sky people chased after Fisher. But Fisher knew that if he didn't make the hole big enough, the sky people would seal it up and winter would rule again. So he kept chewing the sky hole larger, while dodging the arrows of the sky people. Autumn: Finally, however, an arrow struck Fisher just about his tail. He rolled over on his back and began to fall towards the world below. Gitchee Manitou honored him for his bravery and placed him among the stars. Each year he circles the heavens. Running horizontally along the panel's bottom edge are drawings of 13 small spheres representing the 13 moons of the Anishinaabek: Great Spirit Moon, Bear Moon, Snow Crust Moon, Broken Snowshoe Moon, Sugar Moon, Suckerfish Moon, Blossom Moon, Berry Moon, Rice Moon, Changing Leaves Moon, Shedding Leaves Moon, Freezing Moon, and, lastly, Little Spirit Moon.

data.title: Post #11 The Great Prairie
data.listingDescription: Interp information of post #11, the great prairie, of Rankin Ridge Nature Trail at Wind Cave National Park.

images.altText: Post #11 The Great Prairie
images.title: Post #11 The Great Prairie
images.caption: Post #11, The Great Prairie, marks the eleventh stop along the Rankin Ridge Nature Trail.

data.bodyText:
As you reach the crest of the ridge, look to the east and to the prairie beyond. Clearly visible is the zone between forest and prairie. Here open meadows mix with forested hilltops. Under most conditions, the forest expands its range and competes with the prairie for water and space. Wet years provided the moisture that allows young pine seedlings to establish themselves on the prairie. Given time and the right conditions they eventually will crowd out the grasses.

Fire acts as the balancing mechanism, burning off trees and maintaining the prairie. Due to fire suppression practices over the past century, the forest has expanded. With the increase in forest size there has been a corresponding decrease in the amount of water flowing from the mountains. Trees, even ponderosa pines, need more water than grasses, so the streams of the Black Hills are smaller than they used to be, because of fire suppression. Historically, the lands of Wind Cave National Park burned every 8-12 years.
data.audioDescription: Uneven terrain, trail is amongst tall ponderosa trees, and there is a 2 foot wooden post with a number 11 that marks the eleventh stop along the Rankin Ridge Nature Trail.

data.title: Post #13 The Fire Tower—A Reminder of Days Gone By
data.listingDescription: Interp info about post #13, the fire tower, of Rankin Ridge Nature Trail at Wind Cave National Park.

images.altText: Post #13 The Fire Tower
images.title: Post #13 The Fire Tower
images.caption: Post #13 The Fire Tower marks the thirteenth stop of the Rankin Ridge Nature Trail.

data.bodyText: You’ve reached the top of the ridge where the park fire tower stands as a lonely sentinel. Gone are the days of fire lookouts watching for smoke from fire towers. Today’s fire fighters detect smoke over a large area from airplanes. The fire tower is staffed only during periods of extreme fire danger and following intense electrical storms since it provides a panoramic view similar to the one you can see. For safety reasons the fire tower is closed to climbing.
data.audioDescription: Uneven terrain, surrounded by tall ponderosa trees, and a two foot wooden post with the number 13 on it marks the thirteenth stop of the trail.

data.title: Post # 3 Life and Times of Snags
data.listingDescription: Post stop #3 of Rankin Ridge Nature Trail at Wind Cave National Park.

images.altText: Post #3 Life and Times of Snags
images.title: Post #3 Life and Times of Snags
images.caption: Post #3, the Life and Times of Snags, marks the third stop of the Rankin Ridge Nature Trail.

data.bodyText:
One result of the 2005 fire was to leave dead standing trees called snags. You can see some of these to the right of the trail. Snags attract many forms of wildlife. For example some insects, such as longhorned beetles, lay their eggs in slips cut into the bark. When the larvae emerge from the eggs, they initially bore into the nutritious inner bark and eventually tunnel through the wood before developing into adult beetles. Some boreholes may be seen if you look closely at these snags.

The longhorned beetled and the other insects found on the snags are an important food for many types of birds. Over time, the snags may become nesting sites for the common flicker and black-capped chickadee.

data.title: PSSD Wayside- The Legend
data.listingDescription: The Legend and the Manitou Islands and the Sleeping Bear Interpretive Panel

images.altText: Illustration of mother bear and two cubs walking toward a lakeshore
images.title: Wayside: The Legend

data.bodyText:
Once, long ago, in the land called Wisconsin across the great lake, there was terrible hunger and many people died. A bear and two little cubs were trying to leave that place and come around the lake where there would be more food.

They walked for many days on the beach together, but after a while the two little cubs began to whimper with hunger and so the bear decided to swim across the rest of the lake. They waded into the water, one cub on each side of the bear, and they swam off into the lake a long way. After a while the cubs began to get very tired, and so the bear said, Try hard, the land is not very far.' And very soon they did come in sight of land. But gradually the cubs got weaker, and only ten miles away, one cub sank into the water. Soon after the other also drowned.

The bear's heart was broken, but she could do nothing. She waded ashore and lay down, looking out on the water where her cubs had died. Eventually, both of them came to the surface as two little islands, and so the bear still lies there atop the dunes, looking after her children.

data.title: Cottonwood Spring
data.listingDescription: A lush desert oasis that also provides access to the Mastodon Peak Loop and Lost Palms Oasis Trail.

images.altText: A lush desert oasis filled with desert palms, short trees, and shrubs in front of a rocky hill.
images.title: Cottonwood Spring Oasis
images.caption: Cottonwood Spring

data.bodyText: Cottonwood Spring is a lush desert oasis located in the southern portion of the Joshua Tree National Park near the Cottonwood Visitor Center off Cottonwood Spring Road. The spring is a short walk down a dirt path from the parking area, providing an opportunity to see a wide range of plant and wildlife. This trailhead also provides access to longer hikes on the Mastodon Peak Loop and Lost Palms Oasis Trail. The Cottonwood Spring Wilderness Backpacking Board is located at the trailhead for backpackers to self register for overnight backpacking trips in the area.
data.audioDescription: Cottonwood Spring is a lush desert oasis surrounded by rocky hills. The oasis is filled with many types of plants including fan palms, Joshua trees, other small trees, and shrubs. The oasis is located down a short dirt path from a paved parking lot with a paved sidewalk. Next to the trailhead is a backpacking board with information on backpacking as well as a box for self registration as well as an interpretive sign. The area around the parking lot is filled with scattered Joshua trees, short trees, and shrubs.

data.title: Point Park Tour Stop #3 - Garrity's Battery

images.altText: Garrity's Battery, ca. 1900
images.title: Garrity's Battery, ca. 1900
images.caption: Garrity's Battery, ca. 1900

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
data.bodyText: Although these are two 12-pounder Napoleon cannon are situated here today, in 1863, two 10-pounder Parrott cannon occupied this position.
data.audioDescription: Before you is a cast iron tablet and two 12-pounder bronze Napoleon cannon. The guns of Garrity's Battery overlook the city of Chattanooga and Chattanooga Valley, directly below you.

data.title: Barnyard Trail: Woodshed

images.altText: A small red open building
images.title: The Woodshed
images.caption: The woodshed was repurposed from an old smokehouse.

data.bodyText:
“At the time there was no heater in the old house... Never had any coal. All wood. The old wood pile was just north east from the kitchen door, and just to the south of that stood the smoke house where I used to smoke the hams, chops and shoulders...”

- Charles H. Ross, 1913 

The small structure standing before you housed firewood for over 100 years. It was likely adapted from a pig sty which originally stood here. Long before electricity and heating were common features within homes, firewood was a critical resource for keeping warm throughout frigid Long Island winters.  

Mundane though a woodshed may seem, its importance was not lost upon the residents of the Old Mastic House. Cornelia Floyd Nichols remembered: 

“Here are oak, hickory, cedar and apple waiting to yield up the sunshine of many years on our hearth. This is seasoned wood. It has fulfilled all the processes that nature has ordained for complete maturity. Perhaps that is the reason we so often sought the woodshed in moments of stress. To find the right pigeonhole for a grievance, for meditation, or for a good cry, it was an aromatic place of healing.”

data.title: Clinton Visitor Center, near Milepost 89
data.listingDescription: There are many welcome centers up and down the Natchez Trace Parkway that help visitors explore the park and communities near by. One is the Clinton Visitor Center in Clinton, MS just off the Natchez Trace at milepost 89. You can sit in the rocking chairs on the porch and walk the beautiful landscaped grounds. Come by the Clinton Visitor Center, whether you are visiting the city or the Parkway, a newcomer, or a longtime resident. For more details, call 601-924-2221.

images.altText: A brick building with pretty landscaping and a broad porch to visit.
images.title: Clinton Visitor Center
images.caption: Our sister visitor center in Clinton, MS near milepost 89

data.bodyText:
There are many wonderful city or county run welcome centers up and down the Natchez Trace Parkway that help visitors explore the park and communities nearby. One is the Clinton Visitor Center in Clinton, MS just off the Natchez Trace at milepost 89. You can sit in the rocking chairs on the porch and walk the beautiful landscaped grounds.

Come by the Clinton Visitor Center, whether you are visiting the city or the Parkway, a newcomer, or a longtime resident. For more details, call 601-924-2221. 

Hours: 

Monday through Saturday - 9:00 a.am. to 5:00 p.m.
Sunday - 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. 
Closed on major holidays
data.audioDescription: A brick building sits with a parking lot and paved walkway to the front door. It is nicely landscaped with a statue to the side.

data.title: Cottonwood Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Picnic area in cottonwood campground.

images.altText: A covered picnic area with two picnic tables and a grill surrounded by desert shrubs.
images.title: Cottonwood Picnic Area
images.caption: Cottonwood Picnic Area

data.bodyText: The Cottonwood Picnic Area is located by the group sites in the Cottonwood Campground. This picnic area offers covered picnic tables and grills among scattered small trees and shrubs, providing a place for day visitors to enjoy a meal in the park in the southern portion of the park.
data.audioDescription: The cottonwood picnic area is located in a large open area with mountains in the distance. The picnic area has several covered picnic areas with picnic tables and grills. The picnic area is accessed from a paved parking lot on the side of the road with a paved path to a restroom located in the middle of the picnic area. The area is filled with scattered small trees and shrubs.

data.title: Indian Cove Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Picnic area in Indian Cove

images.altText: A picnic table in front of a large rock formation with shrubs scattered around the area.
images.title: Indian Cove Picnic Area
images.caption: Indian Cove Picnic Area

data.bodyText: Indian Cove Picnic Area is located on the east side of the Indian Cove Campground. Picnic tables and grills are nestled among rock formations with scattered shrubs, Joshua trees, and small trees, providing a place for day visitors to enjoy a meal in the park.
data.audioDescription: The Indian Cove Picnic Area is nestled among large rock formations. There are picnic tables and grills mixed among the rocks and scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. There is a dirt parking area on the north side of road and east side of the rock formation with trash cans by the entrance. A pit toiled is located on the opposite side of the road.

data.title: Barnyard Trail: Incinerator

images.altText: A small box made from metal and concrete with a thick metallic door.
images.title: Incinerator
images.caption: The incinerator was a modern solution to an age old problem.

data.bodyText:
In August 1852, Sarah Kirkland Floyd wrote her husband John Gelston Floyd, Sr. about her dismay of the conditions of the barnyard. Martin Van Buren’s son, John, had visited the estate and asked to see the barns. She wrote that she made excuses, “knowing all the time they would not have looked any better if you had been [here], you careless fellow! so they did not go through the gutter now 1/2 a foot deep with green putrid water, or see the vile wood pile & trash around the outbuildings." 

Trash was, as it remains to today, always a struggle to manage. Through the 18th and 19th centuries, the Floyds relied on refuse pits for discarding trash. In the 20th century, the Floyd’s decided to tackle the endless trash problem by installing this incinerator. 

 Archeological digs of refuse pits, outhouses, and land around extant and previous building locations help us date periods of occupation and land use. We have recovered toothbrushes, ceramic dishes, tobacco pipes, and more from these sites.

data.title: Barnyard Trail: Corn Crib

images.altText: A mid-sized building with slated walls.
images.title: The Corn Crib
images.caption: The corn crib featured slated walls to allow for air-flow.

data.bodyText:
This building, called a “corn crib,” was designed with slats in its walls to allow air to circulate and dry the corn for storage. Similar designs were first developed by Native Americans, and later adopted by European colonists. This corn crib was reconstructed by the Floyd family in 1972 after the collapse of a 19th century corn crib in the same location.  

Corn was one of many crops farmed at the William Floyd Estate, but it wasn’t always the primary crop. Oat, flax, wheat, rye, and other grains were the dominant crops here and throughout Long Island in the early 19th century. In his 1804 ledgers, Nicoll Floyd II recorded selling just 10 bushels of Indian corn and 20 bushels of corn. But, by the mid 19th century corn had grown in popularity. In 1860, John Gelston Floyd Sr. wrote that he expected to produce 5000 bushels of corn in the year.

data.title: Land Use Trail: The Vista View

images.altText: A break in a dense tree line is visible from an open field.
images.title: The Vista View
images.caption: The Vista View provided the Estate with a view of the lower acreage and bay.

data.bodyText: The wide break in the trees before you was cleared by John Gelston Floyd Jr. in the late 19th century. Called the “Vista,” this clearing was intended to provide a view to the shore of the bay and allow the ocean breeze to travel up to the house. Around 1900, he established “Meadow Ground Path,” a boardwalk at the end of the Vista to offer guests a way to view the salt meadows without getting their feet wet.

data.bodyText:
This site pin provides audio description for the exhibits in the Anacapa Island Visitor Center.

The Visitor Center is divided into two small rooms. First, the main room with a passport station, exhibit panels and artifacts that describe the natural and cultural history of the island. The adjacent lighthouse lens room to the left of the entrance is displays the original Fresnel lens.

Detailed narrated descriptions of all exhibits and signs are available through our NPS Audio Description Tours mobile app. Visitors may download the iPhone version at the App Store.
data.audioDescription: The Visitor Center is divided into two small rooms. First, the main room with a cement floor, 11 feet wide by 20 feet deep with a bench in the middle, displays a passport station, exhibit panels and artifacts that describe the natural and cultural history of the island. The adjacent lighthouse lens room to the left of the entrance is 11 feet wide by 11 feet deep. The original Fresnel lens on display fills most of the space. MAIN EXHIBIT ROOMAs you enter, moving counterclockwise around the room, wall panel exhibits with text, images and artifact cases illustrate island life, marine mammals, seabirds, rocky reefs, kelp forests, tide pools and human history. Beginning with Island LifeISLAND LIFESelected plants and animals found on the island are displayed in a collage through a series of vibrant photographs each with a caption. Animals on the islandTwo photographs on the upper right of the panel display the deer mouse, peeking its head through a crack in the ground and next the slender salamander, a small brownish black, smooth skinned amphibian with a narrow, almost snake like body, long tail and short stubby legs. Caption reads: Only a few vertebrate animals like the deer mouse and slender salamander live on Anacapa. Visitors rarely see these small secretive animals. Deer mice, the only native land mammals, no longer occur on the east islet. Competition with invading black rats may be part of the cause. Alien rats also prey on native salamanders. Island plantsThree photographs of the giant coreopsis plant illustrate it during different seasons. The first two images show the giant coreopsis in full bloom of yellow, growing in clusters across the landscape. This tall tree like plant grows two to four feet tall with yellow daisy-like flowers, clusters of lacy green leaves on bare trunks two to four inches thick. Caption reads: Giant coreopsis grows only on the Channel Islands and a small section of nearby coast.The next image shows the giant coreopsis in the dry season, the leaves and flowers wither and turn brown, so the plant may appear to be dead, the bare trunks and branches stick out across the landscape like sculptures. Caption reads: Giant Coreposis blooms in profusion following winter rains, but the dry heat of summer sends these woody sunflowers into nine months of dormancy. The next series of four photographs across the bottom of the panel highlight three additional plants found on the island; Gumweed, Indian paintbrush and sea figs. The first two photographs show close ups of gumweed, a compact growing plant with yellow daisy-like flowers. Caption reads: Gumweed, named for its sticky white sap, adds color to summer hikes on Anacapa. Few other plants flower here during the dry season.Next a photograph of the Indian paintbrush, a stunning scarlet red flower contrasts with yellow flowers growing beside it in the image. Each flower is made up of a cluster of smaller trumpet like flowers along the tip of the stem, grouped and tufted like hairs of a paintbrush. Caption reads: Native plants like this Indian paintbrush are among Anacapa's most colorful flowers.The last photograph is of the invasive sea fig. It sprawls low to the ground with pinkish spiny looking blossoms and thick green, fleshy, succulent leaves. Caption reads: Coast Guard employees introduced sea figs to the island for erosion control and landscaping. However, this alien plant competes with native species by crowding them out. Channel Islands National Park strives to protect plants and animals and to eliminate introduced aliens. Next Exhibit Panel MARINE MAMMALSA series of photographs are displayed in a collage featuring whales, dolphins, sea lions and seals, each with caption. A large photograph of the open ocean fills the left third of the panel. The iconic, broad, wedge- shaped tail of a gray whale peeks above the water and is centered in the image. Caption reads Gray whales pass near Anacapa Island on their annual ten-thousand-mile migration between Baja California and the Arctic waters.The next two photographs show the head of a gray whale at the surface of the water. Its skin is blotchy gray and covered with lumpy white barnacles. The baleen, a comb like feeding structure within the whale's mouth, is visible. Captions read:During their round trip journey from Mexico to Alaska, gray whales may pause near the channel island kelp bed to rest or feedBaleen, clearly visible in this whale's mouth, strains small crustaceans from the water during feeding. Barnacles and whale lice give gray whales their blotchy color. Below the gray whales is an image of two orca whales sticking partially out of the water with shiny, jet black bodies and distinctive white eye patches. Their tall, pointed, black dorsal fins protrude, shark like. Then an image of a single dolphin also partially out of the water, with its dark gray back, pointed snout and small dorsal fin.Captions read: Orcas, also called killer whales, hunt prey in small family groups. The

data.audioDescription: Five tactile models of the Channel Islands stretch straight ahead, curving slightly left at the far side of the room. Please use caution, as several wooden display boards hang over each island model, and are likely to knock into one’s head when touching the models. If it is windy, they tend to swing unpredictably as well! Near the center of this table display, a 2 1/4” wide by 1/8” high tactile bar indicates a ½ mile distance: about a 10-minute walk for an adult without physical disabilities. This is the scale for all of the island models in the breezeway. Each island sits on a table with curved edges, depicting the ocean. On the island’s surface, rough textures indicate areas of taller vegetation—brush and trees—often concentrated in valleys and canyons, and on the north shorelines. Let’s now explore this first island. Moving left along the table, about 4 feet from the tactile scale bar, at 10 o’clock, is the first and smallest of the Channel Islands in the National Park: Santa Barbara Island.

data.audioDescription: INTROWelcomeWelcome to the Channel Islands Visitor Center! Thank you for visiting. Please keep in mind that there is always a staff member within earshot. Please feel free to ask if you would like any assistance. Each audio section or subsection will generally provide three things: a general description of any graphics, videos, and displays, a reading of any text associated with that display, and directions to the next exhibit area.And so - let's continue this introduction with an overview of the exhibit space layout. General Space and Layout:This is the upper level of the 1,000 square foot visitor center. Turning with our backs to the counter provides a view of this open space, with tall windows providing views of a native plant garden. Bright graphics on the windows show the scenery and life of the Channel Islands. Most of the Visitor Center is about 2 feet below us, and is accessible by two ramps. The closest one is straight ahead, about 6 feet away. It leads to a gift shop at 1 o'clock. Continuing counterclockwise, at the lower level, are:a tidepool aquarium at 11 o'clock, complete with audio of the ocean, and a graphic mural of waves and birds along the shoreline.the main exhibits, from 11 to 9 o'clock, including the model of an enormous, bellowing bull elephant seal, native American Chumash songs and stories, and a life-sized model of an archaeological dig site. Another ramp back up to this level is at 9 o'clock.If you turn to face the counter, now, we can continue our counterclockwise review of the layout. A changing exhibit area is to the right, at 2 o'clock, about 20 feet away.A tactile display of specimens from the Channel Islands is at the end of this counter, at 2 o'clock.This Visitor Center Desk stretches from 2 o'clock to 9 o'clock.The Breezeway, our next exhibit area, is through doors to the left at 8 o'clock, about 12 feet away. Before heading to the Breezeway, though, it might be helpful to explore a tactile globe and map first, to understand the scale of the Channel Islands in context. Please ask the staff to provide these, if they are available.Globe: The globe of our planet Earth is 12" in diameter, and 1" represents roughly 700 miles, or about a 30 days walk for a fit adult without physical disabilities?. has two large land masses, or continents, that end in a point near the bottom of the globe. The one with the skinniest point is South America. Above this, connected by a thin strip of land, is another continent, North America. On the left side of it, there is a thin peninsula that runs parallel to the coastline. It is Baja California, part of Mexico. The United States begins slightly above the point where the peninsula connects to the mainland. About 1/2 inch above that connecting point you will feel a ridge, running parallel to, and about 1/4" inland, from to the coast of North America. This is the Sierra Mountain range. Although they are too small to feel on this globe, the Channel Islands, are located off the coast, about Â¼" left of the bottom of this ridge. Nation: This map of the United States is scaled so that 1" = 100 miles, or about a 5 days walk for a fit adult without physical disabilities The left , or West, side of the map is bumpier than the right , or East side. On the far left, about a Â½ inch in from the edge of the continent, is a long vertical groove , about the length and width of an adult index finger. This is California's Central Valley, with the Sierra Mountains on the right side and lower coastal mountains on the left. With your fingertip at the very bottom of this valley, the Channel Islands can be found about an inch away, below and slightly to the leftÂ¬-4 tiny bumps in the flat expanse of the Pacific Ocean. California State: The map's scale is 1" = 30 miles, about a 10-hour walk for a fit adult without physical disabilities. On the bottom, or Southern edge, at the coastline, you will feel a bumpy mountain range that heads upward and then (about 6 inches from the bottom) makes a right turn left, or due West, ending in a large bump near the coast in Santa Barbara County. (Keep this bump in mind!. An inch or two below this big bump, you can feel a row of 4 small bumps - the largest Channel Islands. From left to right (West to East), these are San Miguel, Santa Rosa, Santa Cruz, and Anacapa. An inch and a Â½ below Anacapa is the fifth Channel Island in the National Park - Santa Barbara, about the size of a grain of salt. By feeling the rest of the State map, you will get a sense of the powerful tectonic forces that created these islands. Several mountain ranges converge near this point, created by the uplifting pressure of tectonic plates colliding beneath them. Now, for larger models - more than 100 times this size-let's head out to the Breezeway. Pressing together create those bulges. Directions to Tidepool: Following the counter to the left about 11 feet takes us to a 6 foot-long ramp down into the main exhibit area. Continuing straight ahead from the bottom

data.audioDescription: Standing in the doorway of the school house facing inward, the interior is about 16 feet long and 8 feet wide. The walls and ceiling are finished with narrow vertical wooden slat paneling, painted white. The ceiling has a framed inset panel, to access the attic, and a white ceramic ceiling lamp, with a brass mount. The wooden plank floor has a glossy polish. Moving into the room, along the left wall, you will find a framed window with thin wooden mullions containing 12 glass panes; a mounted metal box; a clear plastic pamphlet holder; an information panel; two larger exhibit panels with a low wooden green bench below them; six exhibits with large photographs; and a wall plaque that reads,AcknowledgementsImages of Santa Cruz Island, Santa Rosa Island and Nuestra Senora del RefugioCommemorating Early Land Grants on Both Sides of the ChannelAn exhibition organized by the Santa Barbara Trust for Historic PreservationExhibition Sponsors: The Henry W. Bull FoundationCurators: Carol Storke, Anne Petersen, Curator. SBTHPCuratorial Assistant: Amanda WillifordPhotography and Printing: William B. DeweyGraphic Design: Mary KirkPatrick, Clearview StudioPrint Mounting: Ken KirkPatrick, Anacapa SignsSpecial Thanks:Chris Chapman, Manager, Arroyo Hondo Preserve; Peggy Dahl, Santa Cruz Island Foundation; Marla Daily, President, Santa Cruz Island Foundation; Neal Graffy, Elizabeth Hvolboll, Michael Redmon, Archivist, Santa Barbara Historical Society; Terri Sheridan, Archivist, Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History; Nita Vail, Executive Director, California Rangeland Trust; Kim Walters, Archivist, Southwest Museum; Lynn Weber, Curatorial Volunteer, SBTHP. Will Woolley and the staff, board and many volunteers at the Santa Barbara Trust for Historic Preservation. On the lower right corner of the plaque is the Seal of the Santa Barbara Trust Historic Preservation, a round logo, with a center illustration of an early adobe brick Spanish mission building, with a bell tower with a cross on top.Along the back wall is wooden door, and also two tall closet doors.Along the right wall, from back to front, are two windows; four exhibits with large photos; and another window with a green wooden bench below it.On the floor near the back of the room, are four wooden chairs, arranged in two rows, both facing the front door. Each has a single arm rest that extends and curves out to become a wide flat panel, parallel to the floor. The two chairs have this arm rest panel on the right "arm," and the other two have it on the left "arm."An information panel, titled "Santa Rosa Island Interpretive Guide," is posted on the wall inside the School House.The panel background is a black and white photo showing twelve people on horseback, in front of a wooden fence. Behind it is a thick section of trees. In the distance, to the left, is a large hill.The text reads,Learn more about ranch history, including a complete map and guide to the ranch area, in the Santa Rosa Island Interpretive Guide.The guide also provides detailed information on island Chumash history, military history, and natural history. In addition, it serves as a trail guide for the 1.75 mile hike from the pier to Water Canyon Beach via Cherry Canyon.Borrow the guide and return it or take it home and donate at ciparkfoundation.org/join-support/.Below and to the left of this panel is a small metal box with a locked panel in front, and a slanted top with a slit in the center, about three inches wide. To the right of this box is a wall mounted plastic holder that contains the guides. This exhibit panel, titled "Channel Island Ranchos," provides cultural history about Santa Cruz Island and Santa Rosa Island.The panel background is a faded sepia photo, in shades of brown. It shows a steep, rocky shoreline, with a wooden staircase rising from the beach to the rocky plateau above. On the plateau are a large, long building, two smaller buildings, and canvas tents. The text reads:Santa Cruz Island covers almost 61,000 acres, its fertile central valley girded by rugged mountains, reaching 2,434 feet.Santa Rosa Island encompasses over 54,000 acres, of strikingly different topography - rolling grassy hills, mesas with deep-cut arroyos, and dunes that shift in the almost continuous winds.The Early Years.Humans inhabited the Channel Islands as early as 12,000 years ago. In 1542, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo found populous Chumash villages on Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, and San Miguel islands. The waters of the Santa Barbara Channel teemed with marine life, and the Channel Islands were regular ports of call for fur traders, hunters, and fishermen in the late eighteenth century, although most trade was illegal under both Spanish (1769 to 1821) and Mexican (1821 to 1848) rule. The sea otter population experienced a serious decline by 1820 and the seals by 1830. By 1810 the islanders, victimized by European disease and their economy disrupted, began to migrate to the mainland at the urging of Franciscan padres.Deve

images.title: Signs: Scorpion Ranch Visitor Center
images.caption: Signs: Scorpion Ranch Visitor Center Exhibits

data.bodyText:
This site pin provides audio description for the exhibits in the Scorpion Ranch Visitor Center.

The Visitor Center is divided into two rooms. The first exhibit room was once the dining area and now features exhibits, artifacts, video and computer interactives that describe the Chumash people native to the area, how isolation from the mainland has fostered Santa Cruz Island's unique plants, animals and ways of life and what the National Park Service is doing to protect and restore the island.
The second room was once the ranch kitchen and now features exhibits that describe what it was like to live and work, cook and eat at Scorpion Ranch. The original stove, original radio, interactive audio, exhibit drawers, artifacts and video bring the story to life. A passport stamp station is also available as you enter the room to the left.

Detailed narrated descriptions of all exhibits and signs are available through our NPS Audio Description Tours mobile app. Visitors may download the iPhone version at the App Store.
data.audioDescription: On the valley floor, within the protection of a wide canyon is the Scorpion Ranch housing complex that consists of a two-story ranch house with a kitchen, bakery with a built-in masonry oven, dining area and two rooms upstairs for housing ranch staff. A bunkhouse and a storage shed, about the size of a garage, are also within the 5-foot-high wooden split rail fence that surrounds the compound. Gardens, shrubs and fig trees edge the buildings.The two-story, adobe Scorpion Ranch house, now the visitor center with exhibits, is tucked in close to the canyon walls and faces the open valley to the south. The ranch house was built in 1886 of rubble-wall masonry and rests on a stone and mortar foundation. The building has a rectangular plan that measures 51 feet by 18 feet. It has a shed roof and walls that are 20 inches thick and composed of local stone, adobe bricks, mortar covered with white stucco, and limestone. Windows across the face of the building provide natural light. The first floor has two main rooms, both are open to the public with exhibits and audio visual components that describe the natural and cultural history of the area. The bakery is at the west end of the building and also contains exhibits. The bunkhouse is located immediately south of the adobe ranch house. Built in 1914, this one-and-a-half story wood frame structure has a simple, gable-roof and white board-and-batten siding. A panel at the entrance to the complex reads:Welcome to the Visitor CenterWe invite you to explore this historic ranch building and find out what makes SantaCruz Island like nowhere else on Earth.Investigate the dining room exhibits: discover how isolation from the mainland hasfostered Santa Cruz Island's unique plants, animals and ways of life and learn whatthe National Park Service is doing to protect and restore the island.Wander through the kitchen: listen to stories of living and working at ScorpionRanch.Peek into the bakery: See where bread was baked for the island workers - youmay also hear roosting bats.Take a guided walk or use the interpretive guide: Learn more about the island'shistory and ecology.Interior ExhibitsThe visitor center is on the first level of the ranch house. The two exhibit rooms are full of natural light with white walls and large square terra cotta tile flooring. On the floor, laid out in a figure eight pattern that weaves between both rooms are 19 specially printed floor tiles that tell the history of Santa Cruz Island in timeline format from 8,000 years ago, to 2007. Timeline tiles read:1. Saxipak'a Once upon a time.2. 8,000 years ago Earliest evidence of human life on Santa Cruz Island.3. 2000 years ago Chumash have highly developed technology and systems of transportation and trade.4. 1542 First European explorer, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo, visits the island. At least 1200 Chumash are living on Santa Cruz Island.5. 1769 Santa Cruz Island receives its current name: La Isla de la Santa Cruz.6. 1822 Last of the island Chumash population were relocated to the mainland.7. 1839 The Mexican government grants Santa Cruz Island to Andres Castillero.8. 1857-1869 Santa Cruz Island is owned by William Barron and operated as a sheep ranch. Scorpion is called Rancho del Este9. 1869 San Francisco investors form the Santa Cruz Island Company to develop the island as a ranch. 10. about1880 Justinian Caire, a French immigrant and original investor, acquires sole ownership of Santa Cruz Island and develops a unique island rancho.11. 1912-1932 Litigation envelops Caire's heirs and results in the partition of the island among them.12. 1926 Gherini family (direct descendents of Justinian Caire) retain ownership of the eastern 10% of Santa Cruz Island.13. 1937 Edwin Stanton purchases 90% of Santa Cruz Island.14. 1978 Carey Stanton sells his land on Santa Cruz to The Nature Conservancy. Land use shifts from ranching focus to conservation focus.15. 1980 Channel Islands National Park and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary are established.16. 1997 National Park Service acquires the last interest of the eastern 10% of Santa Cruz Island, including the Scorpion Valley area, from the Gherini family.17. 1999 Last sheep are removed from Santa Cruz Island.18. 2000 The Nature Conservancy transfers 8,500 acres of its holdings on Santa Cruz Island to the National Park Service.19. 2003 Marine Protected Areas are established around Santa Cruz Island and other park islands to restore and preserve marine populations.20. 2006 Bald eagle chicks hatch on Santa Cruz Island for the first time since the 1950s.21. 2007 The National Park Service and The Nature Conservancy complete the removal of non-native mammals from Santa Cruz Island as part of an island conservation program.22. I Sari Wa It will continue indefinitely.The first exhibit room was once the dining area and now features exhibits, artifacts, video and computer interactives that describe the Chumash people native to the area, how isolation from the mainland has fost

data.audioDescription: ORIENTATIONBecause this exhibit shows so many fish and marine mammals, we start with a general description of four tactile items: models of a generic fish, a bottle-nosed dolphin, a grey whale; and a specimen of whale baleen. Please ask the visitor center staff to place these on the counter in front of you, going from your left to your right. We will start by describing the fish on your far left.Generic Tactile Fish Model Description:Although there are approximately 22,000 species of fish in a variety of shapes and sizes, most fish have a shape similar to this generic fish model-shaped like a deflated football or flattened torpedo, balanced on its long, thin edge, with an opening for the mouth in the front, a tall fin on top, a wide flat tail fin in the back, and more thin fins along the sides and bottom. (Please note that there is a two-inch circle indent on one side of this fish model that was caused by the manufacturing process. It is not normally on a fish. The colors are also artificial, so this model is for tactile purposes only.) A more detailed description of the fish model follows.Detail about the Tactile Fish Model:Fish are animals that are cold-blooded, with fins and a backbone. They generally have very small, fine scales that are bony in structure and overlap each other to protect the soft body of the fish. On a live fish, the scales are covered by a slimy mucus layer that helps to prevent infection. The opening you feel on the front end of the fish is its mouth. If you hold the fish horizontally, so the biggest ridge is on top, it will be upright. Above the mouth, on either side of its head, are the fish's eyes. On a real fish, the eyes would not stick out quite so much. Above the eyes, on the top of head are two side-by-side small indents that are called nares. Nares are the nostrils of the fish and detect odors in water. Behind the corners of the mouth is a curved ridge covering the gills. Gills allow the fish to pull oxygen from the water and release carbon dioxide. In a live fish, these gills would open and close about a Â¼ inch every few seconds. Behind the gills are the first of several thin ridges or flaps you will be feeling on this fish, all representing fins. In a live fish under water, these fins would all be sticking away from the body. Fish move all of these fins in order to swim and turn though the water. These first fins, behind the gills, shaped like a flattened tooth, are side or pectoral fins. There is another pectoral fin about four inches behind the first pectoral fin on both sides. On top of the fish is a triangle shaped dorsal fin that sticks up from the body and just behind it is a smaller rounded adipose fin. The fin that sticks out on the bottom of the fish is called the anal fin. At the back of the fish is an upright tail, called a caudal fin, with a slight curve at the end, like a mustache that sticks out further on the top and bottom. This fin generates most of the forward momentum when a fish swims. Behind the front pectoral fins and running along the sides of the fish is a lateral line. The lateral line senses water currents and pressure, and movement in the water. On the bottom of the fish in front of the anal fin is the external opening called the vent. The vent is used for waste elimination and is also where eggs or sperm are released. Remember that the thousands of different species of fish come in a variety in the sizes and shapes. However, they will all have these basic parts, and most are have a shape roughly similar to this model. To the right of the fish is a model of a bottle nosed dolphin.Bottlenose Dolphin Model General DescriptionThe dolphin is upright if you hold it flat, so the middle of the dolphin has a point on the top called a fin. The head is on the pointy end. The head has a short, thick snout, shaped like the top of a long-necked bottle with eyes on either side. Near the head, two flat side blades called flippers stick out and downward on each side. The dolphin is a marine mammal, which means that it is warm blooded and breathes air. It breathes through a small blowhole, an indentation on the top of the head. The body is firm and its tail has a flat v-shape.Their color ranges from light gray to black with lighter coloration on their bellies.The actual adult dolphin is about 25 times bigger than this model. It can grow as big as 12 feet and 1400 lbs. (Please note that there are ridges on the bottom of the model in between the flippers. These were caused by the manufacturing process and are not on a real dolphin). A more detailed description of the model follows.Detail about the Tactile Bottlenose Dolphin Model:Below the dolphin's snout, the mouth is closed. If you were to open the mouth of a real dolphin you would see 18-26 pairs of sharp, conical teeth in each jaw. A dolphin does not chew its food. The teeth are used to grab the often-slippery prey. The corners of the mouth curve upward, giving the dolphin a permanent "smile". Above the snout

data.title: Signs: Santa Barbara Island Visitor Center Exhibits
data.listingDescription: This site pin provides audio description for the exhibits in the Santa Barbara Island Visitor Center. The Visitor Center is one small room with a passport station, exhibit panels and artifacts that describe the natural and cultural history of the island. Detailed narrated descriptions of all exhibits and signs are available through our NPS Audio Description Tours mobile app. Visitors may download the iPhone version at the App Store.
